duck: Formula language, a Lotus Notes programming language
Formula fiction, literature following a predictable form
Formula - In mathematics, a formula is an entity constructed using the symbols and formation rules of a given logical language.
formula definition: a set form of words for use in a ceremony or ritual.
Formula (boats) - Formula is a brand of pleasure boats produced in the United States and sold around the world.

Bill of materials - A bill of materials is a list of the raw materials, sub-assemblies, intermediate assemblies, sub-components, components, parts and the quantities of each needed to manufacture an end product.
Chemical formula, an expression of the contents of a chemical compound
Well-formed formula, a word that is part of a formal language, in mathematical logic

wiki.text:
In science, a 'formula' is a concise way of expressing information symbolically
as in a mathematical or chemical formula. The informal use of the term 'formula'
in science refers to the general construct of a relationship between given
quantities. The plural of formula can be spelled either as formulas or formulae
(from the original Latin).<ref
name="oxford">[http://oxforddictionaries.com/view/entry/m_en_gb0311400 Oxford
Dictionaries: formula].</ref>

In mathematics, a formula is an entity constructed using the symbols and
formation rules of a given logical language. For example, determining the volume
of a sphere requires a significant amount of integral calculus; but, having done
this once, mathematicians can produce a formula to describe the volume in terms
of some other parameter (the radius for example). This particular formula is:
:<math> V =\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3. </math>
Having obtained this result, and knowing the radius of the sphere in question,
we can quickly and easily determine its volume. Note that the volume V and the
radius r are expressed as single letters instead of words or phrases. This
convention, while less important in a relatively simple formula, means that
mathematicians can more quickly manipulate larger and more complex formulae.

In modern chemistry, a chemical formula is a way of expressing information
about the proportions of atoms that constitute a particular chemical compound,
using a single line of chemical element symbols, numbers, and sometimes other
symbols, such as parentheses, brackets, and plus (+) and minus (âˆ’) signs. For
example, H<sub>2</sub>O is the chemical formula for water, specifying that each
molecule consists of two hydrogen (H) atoms and one oxygen (O) atom. Similarly,
O denotes an ozone molecule consisting of three oxygen atoms and having a net
negative charge.

In a general context, formulas are applied to provide a mathematical solution
for real world problems. Some may be general: , which is one expression of
Newton's second law, is applicable to a wide range of physical situations. Other
formulas may be specially created to solve a particular problem; for example,
using the equation of a sine curve to model the movement of the tides in a bay.
In all cases, however, formulas form the basis for all calculations.

Expressions are distinct from formulas in that they cannot contain an equals
sign (=). Whereas formulas are comparable to sentences, expressions are more
like phrases.
wiki.title: formula
